>From: "Chad Bohannan" <chad@...>
> >Well NEAT does have such a compatibility function, so I take your
> >question to be whether you could somehow grade the probability of
> >interspecies mating based on the compatibility of various networks,
> >and the answer is yes. It is possible to do anything you want based
> >on the compatibility function, and using it as a basis for deciding
> >which interspecies matings are tolerable is certainly feasible.
>
>no. I mean what if two mutations are identical but were inovated
>seperatly, so that that they are rated as less compatable. In the early
>part of a search, the ratio of members in a population may be comparable
>to the possible number of node insertion points. So if in the second
>generation, the same mutation occured as had occured in the first
>generation, it would be described as a different gene. Later, as this
>phenomenon happens more than once, measured compatability as returned by
>the compatiablity function wouldn't reflect the identical mutations.
>Am I making a mountain out of a molehill, or am I missing something
>important about the compatibility function?

That really depends on how you handle the assignment of innovation ID's.  
For example, I remember which connection was split to make a node.  Later 
(even hundreds of generations later), if a connection between those two 
nodes is again split, the new node will receive the same node ID as the 
first time.  So if a particular piece of structure happens to evolve twice, 
it is recognized as being the same structure.

Ken's implementation doesn't do that, not between generations anyway.  But 
at the same time, Ken's implementation has managed to evolve solutions to 
things, so obviously it isn't critical.

My suggestion is this:  If you are aware of the possibility of compatible 
structures being seen as incompatible, and that bothers you, and you have 
the time, energy, and know-how to make sure that doesn't happen, then by all 
means, make sure it doesn't happen!  You'll sleep better at night... ;)  
Otherwise, don't worry, NEAT will still work just fine. :)

-- John
